name: (2Z)-2-[4-(4-chlorophenyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]-3-(4-fluorophenyl)prop-2-enenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1245

name: (2Z)-2-[4-(4-chlorophenyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]-3-(4-fluorophenyl)prop-2-enenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1245
Reason: To predict the melting point of the given compound, we need to consider the influence of each functional group and structural feature in the molecule. The basic unit here is a compound similar to biphenyl, which itself has a melting point of around 70 degrees Celsius due to its rigid planar structure. We need to assess each functional group appended to this framework. A thiazole ring is fused to the benzene ring, which introduces nitrogen and sulfur heteroatoms; heteroaromatic rings typically raise the melting point by providing additional rigidity and opportunities for intermolecular interactions, so we might estimate an increase of +30. The chlorine and fluorine substituents are both halogens, which increase the melting point due to their electronegativity and ability to form strong intermolecular interactions like dipole-dipole forces. We can estimate that each halogen might raise the melting point by +20. The cyano group (-C#N) is a polar group that can also engage in dipole-dipole interactions, potentially raising the melting point; however, it is smaller and less polarizable than the halogens, so we might estimate a smaller increase of +10. These adjustments are cumulative, so we add them together: base value (70) + thiazole (30) + 2 halogens (2x20) + nitrile (10).

name: (2Z)-2-[4-(4-chlorophenyl)-1,3-thiazol-2-yl]-3-(4-fluorophenyl)prop-2-enenitrile
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1245
Reason: Starting with a basic biphenyl structure, which has a melting point of around 70 degrees Celsius due to its planar structure and pi-pi stacking opportunities, we then consider the influence of each functional group. The thiazole ring adds rigidity and heteroatoms (N and S), which typically provide stronger intermolecular forces and could increase the melting point by approximately +40. Chlorine and fluorine substituents would significantly raise the melting point because of their high electronegativity and potential for strong intermolecular interactions; for each halogen, a +25 increase is reasonable. The cyano group is a polar and linear group which can engage in dipole-dipole interactions, raising the melting point by about +15. Combining these adjustments: basic unit (70) + thiazole (40) + chlorine (25) + fluorine (25) + nitrile (15).
